summary: samples from 7 patients identified as positive for MERS-CoV were sequenced. these patients were identified by using sequences upstream of the envelope protein gene and open reading frame (ORF) 1a in real-time reverse transcription PCRs (5). index case-patient 1 (PAT001) had traveled to Bahrain, the united arab emirates, and Saudi Arabia during April 24–May 4, 2015. after visiting a local clinic, his symptoms worsened, and he was hospitalized on may 15. he shared a room with PAT003 and the same ward with PAT009, PAT012, PAT013, and PAT015. PCR products were pooled and fragmented to an average of 300 bp. a sequencing library was constructed by using the Illumina TruSeq Nano DNA Sample Prep Kit. 131 reference MERS-CoV S gene sequences from GenBank and MERS-CoV Sequences were aligned by using MUSCLE software (9) phylogenetic analysis of 139 spike glycoprotein gene sequences was performed using RAxML software. tree was visualized with FigTree v.1.4 (http://tree.bio.ed.ac.uk/software/figtree). clades of MERS-CoV are indicated in bold. 183 258 409 1586 1588 1848 1886 3177 3267 (61) (86) (137) (529) (530) (616) (629) (1059) (1059) (1089) JX869059_HCoV-EMC_2012 C (G) T (V) A (S) T (I) G (V) T (V) G (R) T (D) C (S) KR011266_KSA_Hu/Riyad • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • MERS-CoV/KOR/KNIH/001_05_2015 [PAT001] • C (V) • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • MERS-CoV strain ChinaGD01 (KT006149) of 8 nucleotide substitutions, 4 were nonsynonymous. 2 nonsynonymous variants (S137R, I529T, V530L, and R629H) were identified in isolates from PAT002. this mutation rate for the S gene was higher than that for complete MERV-CoV genomes in other studies. more data are required to demonstrate the pattern of MERS-CoV evolution during the outbreak in south Korea because results are limited by a relatively low number of sequences.
